sections.sectionTitle: Euclid's Construction of the Equilateral Triangle

examples.title: Constructing an Equilateral Triangle
examples.statement: Given segment $AB$ of length 3 units, construct an equilateral triangle $ABC$ using only straightedge and compass.

steps: Draw a circle centered at $A$ with radius $|AB| = 3$
Draw a circle centered at $B$ with radius $|BA| = 3$
Let $C$ be one of the intersection points of the two circles
Connect $A$ to $C$ and $B$ to $C$
Since $C$ is on the circle centered at $A$: $|AC| = |AB| = 3$
Since $C$ is on the circle centered at $B$: $|BC| = |BA| = 3$
Therefore $|AB| = |AC| = |BC| = 3$, making $\triangle ABC$ equilateral
solution.conclusion: The triangle $ABC$ is equilateral with all sides of length 3.

exercises.statement: Use Euclid's method to construct an equilateral triangle on each side of a given square. What figure results?
exercises.solution: A regular octagon outline, or more precisely, a square with equilateral triangles on each side, forming a shape with 12 vertices.

exercises.statement: Given a segment $AB$, explain why the two circles in Euclid's construction must intersect.
exercises.solution: Each circle has radius $|AB|$. The distance between centers is also $|AB|$. Two circles intersect when the sum of their radii exceeds the distance between centers and each radius is less than this distance. Here: $|AB| + |AB| = 2|AB| > |AB|$ and $|AB| < |AB| + |AB|$. So the circles must intersect in exactly two points.

examples.title: Constructing a Perpendicular Bisector
examples.statement: Given segment $AB$, construct its perpendicular bisector.

steps: Draw a circle centered at $A$ with radius $|AB|$
Draw a circle centered at $B$ with radius $|BA|$
Let $C$ and $D$ be the two intersection points
Draw line $CD$
This line passes through the midpoint of $AB$ and is perpendicular to $AB$
solution.conclusion: Line $CD$ is the perpendicular bisector of $AB$.

exercises.statement: Why are points $C$ and $D$ (the intersection points in the perpendicular bisector construction) equidistant from both $A$ and $B$?
exercises.solution: Point $C$ lies on the circle centered at $A$ with radius $|AB|$, so $|AC| = |AB|$. Point $C$ also lies on the circle centered at $B$ with radius $|AB|$, so $|BC| = |AB|$. Therefore $|AC| = |BC|$. The same reasoning applies to $D$.

exercises.statement: Construct the angle bisector of a given angle $\angle AOB$.
exercises.solution: Draw a circle centered at $O$ intersecting both rays at points $P$ (on $OA$) and $Q$ (on $OB$). Draw circles of equal radius centered at $P$ and $Q$. Their intersection $R$ (other than any intersection on line $PQ$) lies on the angle bisector. Draw ray $OR$.

examples.title: Geometric Multiplication
examples.statement: Given segments of length $a = 2$, $b = 3$, and a unit segment, construct a segment of length $ab = 6$.

steps: Draw a ray from point $O$
Mark off the unit segment $|OU| = 1$ and segment $|OA| = a = 2$ on this ray
Draw a second ray from $O$ at any angle
Mark off segment $|OB| = b = 3$ on this second ray
Connect $U$ to $B$
Draw a line through $A$ parallel to $UB$, intersecting the second ray at $C$
By Thales' theorem: $\frac{|OC|}{|OB|} = \frac{|OA|}{|OU|}$
So $|OC| = |OB| \cdot \frac{|OA|}{|OU|} = 3 \cdot \frac{2}{1} = 6$

exercises.statement: Using geometric division, construct a segment of length $\frac{5}{3}$ given a unit segment.
exercises.solution: Mark segments of length 5 and 3 on two rays from $O$. If $|OA| = 5$ and $|OB| = 3$ on the respective rays, and $|OU| = 1$ on the first ray, then draw line $AB$ and construct a parallel through $U$ to find the point giving length $\frac{5}{3}$.

examples.title: Using Similar Triangles
examples.statement: If $\triangle ABC \sim \triangle DEF$ with $|AB| = 4$, $|DE| = 6$, and $|BC| = 5$, find $|EF|$.

steps: Since the triangles are similar, corresponding sides are proportional
$\frac{|AB|}{|DE|} = \frac{|BC|}{|EF|}$

exercises.statement: Prove that two triangles with equal corresponding angles are similar.
exercises.solution: If $\angle A = \angle D$, $\angle B = \angle E$, then $\angle C = \angle F$ (since angles sum to $180Â°$). Place $\triangle DEF$ so $D$ coincides with $A$ and $DE$ lies along $AB$. Since $\angle D = \angle A$ and $\angle E = \angle B$, line $EF$ is parallel to $BC$ (alternate angles). By Thales' theorem, $\frac{|AD|}{|AB|} = \frac{|AE|}{|AC|} = \frac{|DE|}{|BC|}$, proving proportionality.
